com.apriori.concurrent

Class PipeliningExecutorService<K>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.apriori.concurrent.PipeliningExecutorService<K>
  • Type Parameters:
    K - the type of keys that identify a pipeline

    public class PipeliningExecutorService<K>
extends java.lang.Object
    An executor that runs multiple sequential pipelines. When tasks are submitted, they are enqueued in a pipeline that runs its tasks sequentially instead of concurrently. However, submitting tasks for multiple pipelines achieves concurrency since pipelines are independent of one another. This is useful for concurrently executing callbacks where order of delivery to a single listener matters. Using the listener as the pipeline key, this executor assures that callbacks are invoked sequentially.

    This executor does not provide a thread pool for concurrent execution. Instead, it wraps another and takes on the parallelism allowed by the wrapped executor. Note: since this executor must maintains its own set of queues, independent of the underlying executor's main work queue (for assuring serial delivery to each pipeline), it is possible for tasks to be accepted by this executor but then later rejected by the underlying executor. Care should be exercised to coordinate the life cycle of the underlying executor and the sources of submissions to pipelines.

      • PipeliningExecutorService

        public PipeliningExecutorService(java.util.concurrent.Executor executor)

    • Method Detail

      • submit

        public <T> ListenableFuture<T> submit(K pipelineKey,
                                      java.util.concurrent.Callable<T> task)
        Submits a task for the specified pipeline. The task can run concurrently with other tasks submitted for different pipelines. It will not execute until all previously submitted tasks for the same pipeline have completed.

        If the task is accepted now but then later rejected by the underlying executor, the returned future will fail and the cause will be a RejectedExecutionException.

        Parameters:
        pipelineKey - the key that identifies the pipeline
        task - a task
        Returns:
        a future that represents the completion of the given task
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if either the pipeline key or task is null

      • submit

        public <T> ListenableFuture<T> submit(K pipelineKey,
                                      java.lang.Runnable task,
                                      T result)
        Submits a task for the specified pipeline. The task can run concurrently with other tasks submitted for different pipelines. It will not execute until all previously submitted tasks for the same pipeline have completed.

        If the task is accepted now but then later rejected by the underlying executor, the returned future will fail and the cause will be a RejectedExecutionException.

        Parameters:
        pipelineKey - the key that identifies the pipeline
        task - a task
        result - the result of the task when it completes
        Returns:
        a future that represents the completion of the given task
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if either the pipeline key or task is null

      • submit

        Submits a task for the specified pipeline. The task can run concurrently with other tasks submitted for different pipelines. It will not execute until all previously submitted tasks for the same pipeline have completed.

        If the task is accepted now but then later rejected by the underlying executor, the returned future will fail and the cause will be a RejectedExecutionException.

        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if either the pipeline key or task is null

      • execute

        public void execute(K pipelineKey,
                    java.lang.Runnable task)
        Executes a task in sequence with others submitted for the same pipeline. The task can run concurrently with other tasks submitted for different pipelines.

        A best effort is made to mark tasks as failed if they are accepted now but then later rejected by the underlying executor. If the task is settable or completable, it will be set/completed with the cause of failure being a RejectedExecutionException. Otherwise, if the task is any other type of Future or Cancellable, then it will be cancelled.

        Note that if the given task is not a form of future task and is not cancellable, the exception is swallowed. Care must be exercised in coordinating task submission with the underlying executor's life cycle to prevent such exception suppression.

        Parameters:
        pipelineKey - the key that identifies the pipeline
        task - a task
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if either the pipeline key or task is null

      • isQuiescent

        public boolean isQuiescent()
        Returns true if this executor has no tasks running or queued.
        Returns:
        true if this executor has no tasks running or queued
        See Also:
        awaitQuiescence()

      • awaitQuiescence

        public void awaitQuiescence()
                     throws java.lang.InterruptedException
        Waits for this executor to reach a point where no tasks are running or queued. Note that this implies nothing about the state of the underlying executor as other sources could still be submitting and running tasks with that executor.

        Note that the state of quiescence may be transient and will end as soon as another task is submitted to this executor. This method is usually used after a source of callbacks is stopped. At that point, no other tasks should be submitted. Once this executor has quiesced, it will then be safe to shutdown the underlying executor. If the underlying executor is shutdown too soon, submissions to this pipelining executor could be rejected with a RejectedExecutionException.

        Throws:
        java.lang.InterruptedException - if the current thread is interrupted while waiting

      • awaitQuiescence

        public boolean awaitQuiescence(long limit,
                               java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit unit)
                        throws java.lang.InterruptedException
        Waits up to the specified amount of time for this executor to reach a point where no tasks are running or queued.
        Parameters:
        limit - the limit of how much time to wait
        unit - the unit for the time limit
        Returns:
        true if quiescence was reached or false if the time limit elapsed first
        Throws:
        java.lang.InterruptedException - if the current thread is interrupted while waiting

      • abortAll

        public java.util.Map<K,java.util.List<java.lang.Runnable>> abortAll()
        Aborts all pipelines, draining their queues and attempting to interrupt any currently running tasks. Note that aborting pipelines this way does not prevent subsequent tasks from being submitted.
        Returns:
        a map of all tasks that were drained, grouped by pipeline key

        public boolean isPipelineQuiescent(K pipelineKey)

        Parameters:

        Returns:
        true if the specified pipeline has no tasks running or queued
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if either the pipeline key or task is null
        See Also:

      • awaitPipelineQuiescence

        public void awaitPipelineQuiescence(K pipelineKey)
                             throws java.lang.InterruptedException
        Waits for the specified pipeline to reach a point where no tasks are running or queued.

        Note that the state of quiescence may be transient and will end as soon as another task is submitted to for the same pipeline key.

        Parameters:
        pipelineKey - the key that identifies the pipeline
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if either the pipeline key or task is null
        java.lang.InterruptedException - if the current thread is interrupted while waiting

      • awaitPipelineQuiescence

        public boolean awaitPipelineQuiescence(K pipelineKey,
                                       long limit,
                                       java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit unit)
                                throws java.lang.InterruptedException
        Waits up to the specified amount of time for the specified pipeline to reach a point where no tasks are running or queued.

        Note that the state of quiescence may be transient and will end as soon as another task is submitted to for the same pipeline key.

      • abortPipeline

        public java.util.List<java.lang.Runnable> abortPipeline(K pipelineKey)
        Aborts the specified pipeline by draining its queue and attempting to interrupt its currently running task. Aborting the pipeline does not prevent subsequent tasks from being submitted for the same pipeline key.
        Parameters:
        pipelineKey - the key that identifies the pipeline
        Returns:
        the list of tasks that were drained from the pipeline's queue
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if either the pipeline key or task is null

      • newExecutorServiceForPipeline

        public ListenableExecutorService newExecutorServiceForPipeline(K pipelineKey)
        Creates a new service whose tasks are submitted to the specified pipeline. Shutting down the returned service only affects submissions to the pipeline made by that service. Other tasks submitted from other sources will continue to be accepted. Similarly, shutting down the returned service in no way affects this PipeliningExecutorService, nor its underlying executor.

        This method is an adapter. For APIs that expect an ExecutorService, you can use this to construct an executor that acts like a single-threaded executor and interleaves tasks with others for the same pipeline.

        Parameters:
        pipelineKey - the key that identifies the pipeline
        Returns:
        a new executor service whose tasks are submitted to the given pipeline
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if either the pipeline key or task is null
